indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. The number of sites cleaned 2. Volumes of POP pesticides or conterminated soil treated . 3. Compliance with international standards for pesticide stockpiles management 4. Government budget allocations adequate to destroy stockpiles and to manage contaminated sites in future

baseline.comment: According to MONRE data in 2010, there are more than 1000 contaminated sites in Vietnam that have potential adverse impact to people leaving around the sites. Foods produced from the high concentrated POP pesticide sites once taken by people will effect the health of those people. Also, there are no standards and guidance for management and destruction of POP pesticide in 2010, which local people and authority is not well aware of risks to their life and treatment methods. The Government expenditure for this activities in 2006 is rather modest with an amount of USD 382,000

target.comment: 1. Clean at least 5 contaminated sites in Nghe An-Ha Tinh 2. Collect 700 tones high Pop pesticides contaminated soil 3. treat at least 50% collected soil in Holcim company site and properly isolate 5000 m3 of low POP contain soil 4. Improve knowledge and capacity of provincial staff on management and treatment of contaminated site by using standard Environmental Management Plan (EMP) guideline

actual.comment: 1.1. 10 sites cleaned 2. 626.3 tones high Pop pesticides contaminated soil collected and 566.5 tones collected soil fully treated at Holcim company 3. 5200 m3 of low POP contain soil isolated in Mau Hai, Thach Luu and Hon Tro 4. 99 provincial staff has improved knowledge and capacity on on management and treatment of contaminated site through 2 EMP training course using technical guideline in line with international standard

target.comment: 1. Further collect 170 tones high Pop pesticides contaminated soil 2. Further carry out 3 training courses for provincial staff 3. Complete Database software and M&E indicators for testing to contribute to national capacity on contaminated site management 4. Carry out non-combustion technology pilot and share information with provinces

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Indicator 1: Mechanism for monitor the progress of implementing the Strategies introduced and adopted. Indicator 2: Available and strengthened mechanism to improve aid coordination and multi-stakeholder participation in law and justice sector reform. Indicator 3: Number of initiatives to enhance capacity of justice institutions and personnel in justice sector planning and coordination. Indicator 4: Drafting process to ensure gender mainstreaming in legislation introduced and adopted. Indicator 5: Number of laws drafted and endorsed following rights-based approach and ensure greater coherence with international human rights standards. Indicator 6: Established mechanism to support National Steering Committee on Judicial Reform's decision-making process on a number of cross-cutting policy issues.

baseline.comment: 1. Mechanism for monitoring the overall progress of implementing strategies does not exist due to the lack of coordination by individual justice institutions. 2. Mechanism for aid coordination in law and justice sector reform does not exist. Weakness in aid coordination in legal and judicial sectors resulted in overlap and low level of synergy. 3. Limited capacity of the justice institutions in sector wide planning and coordination, in particular in the areas of statistical system, monitoring and reporting. 4. Standardized requirements and process to ensure gender mainstreaming in legislation does not exist. 5. Laws being drafted without assessment of the potential impacts to rights holders to ensure the realization of Vietnam commitments to international human rights bodies. 6. Mechanism not available to support the National Steering Committee for Judicial Reform on judicial reform decision making.

target.comment: In 2014, main targets of the project are: 1. Mechanism for monitor the progress of implementing the Legal System Development and Implementation Strategy adopted. 2. A new platform for knowledge sharing and update on aid coordination in law and judicial sector created, in complementary to the existing policy forums and dialogues. 3. Increased capacity of the justice sector personnel in law development and implementation. 4. Use of the gender mainstreaming drafting tool in the drafting of the Law on Civil Status; Identified measures to improve women's access to judicial services. 5. Supported legislative changes toward building a stronger law-based society with pro-poor policies, increased access to justice and protection of citizens’ rights with focus to the Penal Code amendment and the Law on Civil Status. 6. Strengthened mechanism to support the judicial reform decision making through cross-cutting research and policy advisory service to strengthen the central role of the court in improving access to justice and protection of citizens’ rights.

actual.comment: Key results are: 1. The mechanism for 8-year review of the Legal System Development and Implementation Strategy adopted with the participation of independent experts. 2. Launched a shared portal for knowledge sharing and informing on the justice sector's international cooperation, information and documentation on law and judiciary reform available for public use. 3. Improved capacity of the MOJ staff to improve its performance and ranking as reviewed by the Ministerial Effectiveness Index of Business Law Development and Implementation (MEI). 4. Completion of the assessment on women's access to judicial services in Viet Nam and recommended solutions to address gender inequality and to facilitate women’s access to judicial services. 5. Completed a comprehensive review of the Penal Procedure Code through the lens of international human rights law and standards, concrete recommendations to improve the law in forthcoming amendments sent to Supreme Procuracy, National Assembly and Central Committee for Internal Affairs; Supported advocacy for equal rights of LGBT people, the rights of women and children in the making of the Law on Civil Status, see UN joint recommendations to the draft Law on Civil Status. 6. Through the established mechanism to support judicial reform decision making, policy advisory provided to address main challenges in reforming the court system, including the effectiveness of the court-annexed conciliation, and the court restructure at different jurisdictions.

target.comment: In 2015, the project is extended for 9 months, aiming to fulfill the main targets below: 1. Built on the 2014 result, the mechanism of 8-year review of the Legal System Development and Implementation Strategy resulted in a comprehensive assessment with policy recommendations to be submitted to the Central Committee for Internal Affairs (CCIA). 2. Support to implementation of the new Decree on aid coordination and international cooperation in law, judicial reform. 3. No target for 2015. 4. No target for 2015. 5. Ensured rights-based and due process in law reform, with focus on the amendments of the Penal Code and the Civil Code, and the implementation of the Constitution amendments. 6. Continued to support the judicial reform decision making through cross-cutting research and policy advisory service to strengthen the central role of the court in improving access to justice and protection of citizens’ rights.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1.1 Availability of a staff recruitment mechanism based on merit and competencies. Scaling from 0-3, where: 0: mechanism not available, 1: draft mechanism being prepared and shared for consultations, 2: draft mechanism finalized and going through the formal approval process, 3: mechanism approved and implemented. 1.2 Availability of a staff performance appraisal system (integrated into the staff management information system). Scaling from 0-3, where: 0: system not available, 1: draft system being prepared and shared for consultations, 2: draft system finalized and going through the formal approval process, 3: system approved and implemented. 1.3 Number of civil servants using the staff performance appraisal system on regular basis. 1.4 Availability of a mechanism for result-based remuneration for civil servants. Scaling from 0-3, where: 0: mechanism not available, 1: draft mechanism being prepared and shared for consultations, 2: draft mechanism finalized and going through the formal approval process, 3: mechanism approved and implemented. 1.5 Availability of a training programme specialized for different categories of civil servants. Scaling from 0-3, where: 0: training programme not available, 1: draft training programme being prepared and shared for consultations, 2: draft training programme finalized and going through the formal approval process, 3: training programme approved and implemented. 1.6 Availability of a modern staff management information system (including staff recruitment, performance appraisal, training, etc.). Scaling from 0-3, where: 0: system not available, 1: draft system being prepared and shared for consultations, 2: draft system finalized and going through the formal approval process, 3: system approved and implemented. 2.1 Availability of a set of indicators and toolkits for assessment of satisfaction with the quality of public administrative services. Scaling from 0-3, where: 0: indicators and toolkits not available, 1: draft indicator

baseline.comment: 1.1 Rating: 0. Non-existence of a staff recruitment process based on merit and competencies. Current staff recruitment process is not based on competencies but mainly relies on diplomas, and certificates. 1.2 Rating: 0. Non-existence of a result-based staff performance appraisal system. A set of indicators and criteria to assess work performance of civil servants are being developed. 1.3 Zero civil servant use the staff performance appraisal system, which has not been made available at the beginning of the project. 1.4 Rating: 0. Non-existence of a mechanism for result-based remuneration for civil servants. Remuneration policies for civil servants are not based on merits but rather on performance-unrelated diplomas and seniority. 1.5 Rating: 0. Non-existence of a training programme specialized for different categories of civil servants. Civil servant structure is not available, without job description for each position. Education and training provided to civil servants is not based on job positions’ requirements. 1.6 Rating: 0. Non-existence of a modern staff management information system (including staff recruitment, performance appraisal, training, etc.). Current staff management information system needs to be upgraded towards online, and integrated with new modules such as staff recruitment, performance appraisal, training… 2.1 Rating: 0. Non-existence of a specialized and independent unit and standard tools for measuring the quality of public administrative services delivered to citizens and organizations. 2.2 Zero online feedbacks by citizens and organizations on quality of public administrative services delivery.

target.comment: 1.1 Rating: 1. 01 toolkit and guidelines for staff recruitment process developed. 1.2 Rating: 1. 01 set of indicators for result-based staff performance developed. 1.3 The newly-developed set of indicators piloted for civil servants at provincial departments and head of commune people’s committees. 1.4 Rating: 1. 01 draft proposal on mechanism for result-based remuneration for civil servants developed. 1.5 Rating: 1. 01 training curriculum for development of staff structure with job description for each position developed. 1.6 Rating: 1. 02 modules of staff management software developed. 2.1 Rating: 1. 01 set of indicators for assessment of users’ satisfactions on quality of public administrative services developed. 2.2 15,000 feedbacks on public administrative services provided online.

actual.comment: 1.1 Rating: 1. 01 proposal on recruitment procedures (incl. 1 toolkit, guidelines, bank of questionnaires and 1 software application module) developed and ready for installations in all 20 provincial Departments and 7 districts. 1.2 Rating: 1. 02 proposals (02 set of indicators) on performance appraisal for i) employees of public service delivery agencies (PSDA); and ii) chairmen of commune People’s Committees developed 1.3 The newly-developed set of indicators piloted at all provincial departments and used to assess performance of all people’s committees chairperson at commune level. 1.4 Rating: 2. 01 proposal on mechanism for results-based remuneration developed and submitted to the Government (Ministry of Home Affairs, Ministry of Finance, Office of the Government) for approval. 1.5 Rating: 1. 01 training curriculum for development of staff structure with job description for each position. As a result, 14,000 positions has been developed with job description. 1.6 Rating: 2. 03 modules of staff management software developed: staff recruitment, staff performance appraisal and e-cards for 27,987 civil servants. 2.1 Rating: 1. 01 set of indicators for online assessment of users’ satisfactions on quality of public administrative services developed. 2.2 28,360 online feedbacks on public administrative services provided at one-stop-shops.

target.comment: 1.1 Rating: 1. The newly-developed recruitment guidelines piloted in all 20 provincial departments and districts (using software application). 1.2 Rating: 3. The performance appraisal system finalized and submitted to relevant authorities (Ministry of Home Affairs, Office of the Government) for approval of official application. 1.3 100% civil servants of Da Nang use the newly developed performance appraisal system on regular basis. 1.4 Not applicable, as there is no 2015 target for this indicator. 1.5 Rating: 2. 02 training curricula developed by Ministry of Home Affairs (MOHA) for different categories of civil servants reviewed and customized, taking into consideration of Da Nang context. 1.6 Not applicable, as there is no 2015 target for this indicator. 2.1 Rating: 3. 01 set of indicators for online assessment of users’ satisfactions on quality of public administrative services reviewed and revised. Other tools for collecting feedbacks from users developed. 2.2 60,000 online feedbacks on public administrative services provided on one-stop-shops performance. 5,000 direct feedbacks from other channels.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Number of policy dialogues between central and local levels and among localities on PAR issues organized. 2.1 Number of local PAR initiatives in Bac Giang, Can Tho, Da Nang and Ha Tinh supported. 2.2 Number of good practices piloted in 4 localities Bac Giang, Can Tho, Da Nang and Ha Tinh used/replicated by other localities. 2.3 Number of good practices, documents and publications (i.e movie) reflecting lessons drawn from local PAR initiatives. 2.4 Number of national regulations developed/revised, using inputs from 4 local projects.

baseline.comment: 1. Non-existence of regular dialogues between central and local levels and among localities on PAR issues. 2.1 Local PAR initiatives in Bac Giang, Can Tho, Da Nang and Ha Tinh received limited technical support from the Ministry of Home Affairs (MOHA). 2.2 Non-existence of PAR good practices on public human resource reform and public administration service delivery in 4 localities Bac Giang, Can Tho, Da Nang and Ha Tinh. 2.3 Local knowledge and experiences on PAR are not gathered, processed and documented for systematic, wide and continuous circulation. 2.4 Local initiatives on public human resource reform and public administration service delivery are not effectively used by MOHA for national regulations development/revision.

target.comment: 1. 01 policy dialogue between central and local levels and among localities on PAR issues organized. 2.1 02 local PAR initiatives in Bac Giang, Can Tho, Da Nang and Ha Tinh supported. 2.2 01 initiative piloted in one locality used/replicated by other localities. 2.3 03 good practices, reflecting lessons drawn from local PAR initiatives, documented. 2.4 01 proposal provided to MOHA for consideration in development of national regulations on PAR.

actual.comment: 1. 02 policy dialogues between central and local levels and among localities on PAR issues organized. 2.1 07 local PAR initiatives in Bac Giang, Can Tho, Da Nang and Ha Tinh supported. 2.2 01 software application for public human resource management in Da Nang city customized and piloted in Can Tho city. 2.3 03 good practices, reflecting lessons drawn from local PAR initiatives, documented. 01 website developed and used for information sharing among PAR projects. 2.4 01 draft proposal on minimum data managed by provincial public human resource management information system (HRMIS).

target.comment: 1. 03 policy dialogue between central and local levels and among localities on PAR issues organized. 2.1 10 local PAR initiatives in Bac Giang, Can Tho, Da Nang and Ha Tinh supported. 2.2 03 initiative piloted in one locality used/replicated by other localities. 2.3 05 good practices, reflecting lessons drawn from local PAR initiatives, documented. 2.4 02 proposals provided to MOHA for consideration in development of national regulations on PAR.

baseline.comment:
At the beginning of 2013:
1. Number of approved guidelines for National REDD+ Action Plan implementation: 0 2. Number of fund created and operated for mobilizing investment in REDD+ : 0 3. Number of site REDD+ action plan: 0 4. Number of people benefiting from Site activities: 0 5. Number of policy/design options for benefit sharing from result-based payment:0 6. Number of Grievance mechanisms for REDD+:0 7. Number of Safeguards Information System created to monitor impacts of - REDD+ interventions on Safeguards: 0

target.comment: 1. 01 Interim guideline for provincial REDD+ action plan development is drafted. 2. 01 proposal for National REDD+ fund establishment is put under consultation process with stakeholders and finalized 3. Develop 06 Site REDD+ action plans 4. 4000 people benefited from site activities 5. 01 proposal on design of benefit sharing system (or Incentive Allocation System) is drafted. 6. 0 Grievance mechanisms for REDD+ is designed 7. 0 Safeguards Information System created to monitor impacts of - REDD+ interventions on Safeguards

actual.comment: 1. 01 Interim guideline for provincial REDD+ action plan development is drafted. 2. 01 proposal for National REDD+ fund establishment is drafted and put under consultation process with stakeholders 3. 02 Site REDD+ action plans 4. 1000 people benefited from site activities (of which 51% are female) 5. 0 design proposal for benefit sharing is proposed 6. 0 Grievance mechanisms for REDD+ is designed 7. 0 Safeguards Information System created to monitor impacts of - REDD+ interventions on Safeguards

target.comment: 1. 01 guideline for provincial REDD+ action plan development is finalised and adopted by Gov. 2. 01 decision of Gov. approving the proposal for National REDD+ fund establishment 3. 14 Site REDD+ action plans 4. 14000 people benefiting from site activities (of which 51% are female) 5. 01 design proposal for benefit sharing is proposed 6. 01 proposal for the development of GRM of REDD+ is submitted for consultation with stakeholders 7. 0 Safeguards Information System created to monitor impacts of - REDD+ interventions on Safeguards

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Number of strategic leaders being trained with the revised gender-sensitive curriculum at the Ho Chi Minh Political Academy (HCMA). 2. Number of female officials participated in Women’s Leadership Program that was developed and institutionalized in HCMA. 3. Representation of women in Party Committees, National Assembly and People’s Councils 4. Number of female National Assembly and People's Councils candidates who have access to training courses on soft skills and participate in a mentoring programme to prepare for the election. 5. Availability of the human resource procedures that promote women’s participation in leadership positions 6. Number of female officers who have access to the research grant program 7. Number of draft laws that have gender analysis conducted and fed to national law drafting team and National Assembly members

baseline.comment: 1.Existing training programs at the HCMA, its sub academies, and 63 provincial political schools are gender blind. 2. Women in the public sector have limited access to professional leadership training programs run by government institutions. Few women civil servants receive training in leadership or management skills 3. For the 2011-2016 term, the percentage of women is 9% for the Central Committee of the Communist Party, 24.4% for the National Assembly, and less than 28% for the People’s Councils at all levels. 4. In the 2011 election, no women candidates participated in a mentoring programme 5. The current hiring, promotion and selection for training process in the civil service have not met the targets of the Strategy on Gender Equality. 6. 43 female officers were awarded research grants since 2009. However, the quality of their research and their understanding of gender mainstreaming still varies.

target.comment: 1. At least 200 strategic leaders being trained with the revised gender-sensitive curriculum at the Ho Chi Minh Political Academy 2. The Women's Leadership Program developed and piloted at HCMA 3. Potential candidates were better prepared for 2016 elections through the development and dissemination of Manual for Mentoring Programme Coordinators and a joint action plan between Fatherland Front and Women's Union to increase women's representation on election ballots and to meet targets of National Strategy for Gender Equality. 4. At least 1500 officers have access to training courses on soft skills. 5. The guidelines for human resource officials and senior managers in the development and implementation of human resource strategies developed and disseminated 6. 15 female officers have access to the research grant program 7. Two draft laws that have gender analysis conducted and fed to national law drafting team and National Assembly members

actual.comment: 1. UNDP worked with Ho Chi Minh National Academy of Politics to mainstream gender The curriculum of Strategic Leadership Training Course. We also developed a 2-day gender module and incorporated it into the course curriculum. 288 strategic leaders (many of them are at the vice minister-level up) have been trained with this revised gender-sensitive curriculum. 2. The Women's Leadership Program was developed. One pilot training was conducted with participation of 30 female government officers. 3. The Manual for Mentoring Programme Coordinators was developed, which provides a new and effective capacity building approach for women leaders. 920 staff of about 10 agencies have got access to this Manual. HCMA and Women’s Union were supported to pilot a mentoring programme in their organizations. An action plan was developed jointly by Fatherland Front and Women's Union that set out necessary actions to increase women's representation on election ballots and to meet targets of National Strategy for Gender Equality 4. 1,720 female officers in the public sector participated in UNDP-supported training on leadership skills 5. The guidelines for human resource officials and senior managers in the development and implementation of human resource strategies developed and disseminated. Training to personnel officers and action plan developed at provincial level on gender sensitive human resource practices 6. 15 female officers have access to the research grant program 7. Civil society organizations were supported to do gender analysis of the draft Law on Organization of National Assembly and the Election Law, to conduct wider consultation on recommendations for amendments and to feed these recommendations to the law drafting team and National Assembly members

target.comment: 1. 100 strategic leaders being trained with this revised gender-sensitive curriculum. 2. The Women's Leadership Program was finalized and 40 trainers benefited from the TOT training. 3. At least 800 potential candidates for National Assembly and People's Council trained on leadership skills; At least 80 trainers trained and then provided training for potential candidates on leadership skills; The Leadership Training Manual developed and disseminated to 63 provinces and widely used by potential candidates; An e-learning course developed and posted on internet for free access of potential candidates. 4. At least 250 female officers in the public sector participated in UNDP-supported training on leadership skills. 5. At least 120 people being trained on mainstreaming gender into HR practices. 6. N/A 7. At least 1 draft law (Law on Organisation of Government) that has gender analysis conducted and fed to national law drafting team and National Assembly members

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. M& E mechanism for Viet Nam Green Growth Strategy and Action Plan 2. Guideline on green growth investment. 3. Guideline for preparation of sectoral and provincial green growth action plan. 4. Number of sectoral and provincial GG action plans with GHG emission targets. 5. Communication action plan, and number of events and media coverage. 6. Number of policy studies and dialogues relating to green investments, green transportation, green procurement and financial tools for green development. 7. Level of availability of financial data and information to interested stakeholders. 8. Number of report on climate public and private expenditures. 9. Number of green growth projects ideas and proposals.

baseline.comment: 1. M& E mechanism is not in place. 2. No guideline is in place. 3. No guideline is in place. 4. No GG action plan has been formulated for target sectors and provinces. 5. Communication action plan is not in place. 6. Limited studies have been produced by other development partners. 7. A UNDP-WB supported website in place and some scattered information in various websites. 8. No report on climate finance expenditures produced; 9. No green growth projects ideas and proposals by businesses in place

target.comment: not applicable as the project started early 2015

actual.comment: not applicable as the project started early 2015

target.comment: 1. The M& E mechanism for Viet Nam Green Growth Strategy drafted 2. Not a target for 2015, for it is for 2016. 3. Guidelines for preparation of sectoral and provincial green growth action plans approved. 4. Two provincial Green Growth action plans with GHG emission reduction targets formulated. 5. Not a target for 2015, it is for 2016. 6. Five report of studies on green transportation and financial tools for green development, prepared. 7. Not a target for 2015, it is for 2016 and 2017 8. One report on national climate public expenditure and investment review completed and launched. 9. Not a target for 2015, it is for 2016, 2017, and 2018
